questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 4871, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that first digit in $$\color{red}4 \color{black}871$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 4 or round it up to 5. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 4 in $$4 \color{red}8\color{black}71$$, which is 8. Given that $$8 \geq 5$$, we round 4 up to 5 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, first result is 5000 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second digit in $$4 \color{red}8\color{black}71$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 8 or round it up to 9. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 8 in $$4 8\color{red}7\color{black}1$$, which is 7. Given that $$7 \geq 5$$, we round 8 up to 9 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the second result is 4900  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 3 significant figures means that third digit in $$48\color{red}7\color{black}1$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 7 or round it up to 8. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 7 in $$487\color{red}1\color{black}$$, which is 1. Given that $$1 \lt 5$$, we keeep the 7 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the third result is 4870 $$\\$$ Notice that the greater the number of s.f the number is closer to 4871

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 4570 , we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that first digit in $$\color{red}4 \color{black}570$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 4 or round it up to 5. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 4 in $$4 \color{red}5\color{black}70$$, which is 5. Given that $$5 \geq 5$$, we round 4 up to 5 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, first result is 5000 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second digit in $$4 \color{red}5\color{black}70$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 5 or round it up to 6. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 5 in $$4 5\color{red}7\color{black}0$$, which is 7. Given that $$7 \geq 5$$, we round 5 up to 6 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the second result is 4600  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 3 significant figures means that third digit in $$45\color{red}7\color{black}0$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 7 or round it up to 8. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 7 in $$457\color{red}0\color{black}$$, which is 0. Given that $$0 \lt 5$$, we keeep the 7 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the third result is 4570 $$\\$$ Notice that the greater the number of s.f the number is closer to 4570

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 4136, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that first digit in $$\color{red}4 \color{black}136$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 4 or round it up to 5. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 4 in $$4 \color{red}1\color{black}36$$, which is 1. Given that $$1 \lt 5$$, we keep the 4 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, first result is 4000 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second digit in $$4 \color{red}1\color{black}36$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 1 or round it up to 2. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 1 in $$4 1\color{red}3\color{black}6$$, which is 3. Given that $$3 \lt 5$$, we keep the 1 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the second result is 4100  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 3 significant figures means that third digit in $$41\color{red}3\color{black}6$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 3 or round it up to 4. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 3 in $$413\color{red}6\color{black}$$, which is 6. Given that $$6 \gt 5$$, we round the 3 up to 4 and the rest of digits becomes zero. Thus, the third result is 4140$$\\$$ Notice that the greater the number of s.f the number is closer to 4136

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 0.02569, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that first s.f in $$0.0\color{red}2\color{black}569$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 2 or round it up to 3. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 2 in $$0.02 \color{red}5\color{black}69$$, which is 5. Given that $$5 \gt 5$$, we round the 2 up to 3. Thus, first result is 0.03 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second s.f in $$0.02 \color{red}5\color{black}69$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 5 or round it up to 6. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 5 in $$0.025\color{red}6\color{black}9$$, which is 6. Given that $$6 \gt 5$$, we round the 5 up to 6. Thus, the second result is 0.026  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 3 significant figures means that third s.f in $$0.025\color{red}6\color{black}9$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 6 or round it up to 7. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 6 in $$0.025\color{red}9\color{black}$$, which is 9. Given that $$9 \gt 5$$, we round the 6 up to 7. Thus, the third result is 0.0257$$\\$$Notice that the greater the number of s.f the number is closer to 0.02569

questions.Q: By rounding to 1 and 2 significant figures 2.580, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that the first s.f in $$ \color{red}2.\color{black}580$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 2 or round it up to 3. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 2 in $$2.\color{red}5\color{black}80$$, which is 5. Given that $$5 \ge 5$$, we round the 2 up to 3. Thus, first result is 3 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second s.f in $$ 2.\color{red}5\color{black}80$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 5 or round it up to 6. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 5 in $$2.5\color{red}8\color{black}0$$, which is 8. Given that $$8 \gt 5$$, we round the 5 up to 6. Thus, the second result is 2.8

questions.Q: By rounding to 1 and 2 significant figures 9.87, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that the first s.f in $$ \color{red}9.\color{black}87$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 9 or round it up to 10. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 9 in $$9.\color{red}8\color{black}7$$, which is 8. Given that $$8 \gt 5$$, we round the 9 up to 10. Thus, first result is 10 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second s.f in $$ 9.\color{red}8\color{black}7$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 8 or round it up to 9. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 8 in $$9.8\color{red}7\color{black}$$, which is 7. Given that $$7 \gt 5$$, we round the 8 up to 9. Thus, the second result is 9.9

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 1.2, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that the first s.f in $$ \color{red}1.\color{black}2$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 1 or round it up to 2. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 1 in $$1.\color{red}2\color{black}$$, which is 2. Given that $$2 \lt 5$$, we keep the 1. Thus, first result is 1 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f}\color{black}\\$$ There is nothing to do, 1.2 has 2 s.f $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f}\\$$ Recall that trailing zeros in a decimal number count as significant figures, therefore, the third result is 1.20

questions.Q: By rounding to o1, 2 and 3 significant figures 1.8, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that the first s.f in $$ \color{red}1.\color{black}8$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 1 or round it up to 2. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 1 in $$1.\color{red}8\color{black}$$, which is 8. Given that $$2 \gt 5$$, we round 1 up to 2. Thus, first result is 2 $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f}\color{black}\\$$ There is nothing to do, 1.8 has 2 s.f $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f}\\$$ Recall that trailing zeros in a decimal number count as significant figures, therefore, the third result is 1.80

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 100, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \\$$ There is nothing to do, 100 has 1 significant figure, but it can also be written as $$1\times 10^2$$.  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \\$$ Since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 1.0\times 10^2 \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f}\color{black}\\$$Similarly, since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 1.00\times 10^2$$

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2 and 3 significant figures 5000, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \\$$ There is nothing to do, 5000 has 1 significant figure, but it can also be written as $$5\times 10^3$$.  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \\$$ Since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 5.0\times 10^3 \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f}\color{black}\\$$Similarly, since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 5.00\times 10^3$$

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2, 3  and four significant figures 0.05, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \\$$ There is nothing to do, 0.05 has 1 significant figure, so we can express the answer either as $$0.05$$ or but it can also be written as $$5\times 10^{-2}$$.  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \\$$ Since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 5.0\times 10^{-2} \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f}\color{black}\\$$Similarly, since the number has fewer significant figures than requested, we need to use scientific notation. $$\\ 5.00\times 10^{-2} \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 4 s.f}\color{black}\\$$For the same reason as before, $$\\ 5.000\times 10^{-2}$$

questions.Q: By rounding to 1, 2, 3, four and five significant figures 2840000, we get:
questions.E: $$\color{blue}\text{Rounding to 1 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 1 significant figure means that the first s.f in $$ \color{red}2\color{black}840000$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 2 or round it up to 3. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 2 in $$2\color{red}8\color{black}40000$$, which is 8. Given that $$8 \ge 5$$, we round the 2 up to 3. Thus, first result is 3000000 or $$3\times10^6 \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 2 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 2 significant figures means that second s.f in $$ 2\color{red}8\color{black}40000$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 8 or round it up to 9. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 8 in $$28\color{red}4\color{black}0000$$, which is 4. Given that $$4 \lt 5$$, we keep the 8. Thus, the second result is 2800000 or $$2.8\times10^6 \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 3 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Having 3 significant figures means that the third s.f in $$ 28\color{red}4\color{black}0000$$ is uncertain. We need to define if we should keep the 4 or round it up to 5. To do that, we need to check the digit next to 4 in $$284\color{red}0\color{black}000$$, which is 0. Given that $$0 \lt 5$$, we keep the 4. Thus, the third result is 2840000 or $$2.84 \times 10^6 \\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 4 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ Here, we need to use scientific notation and the result is $$\\ 2.840\times 10^{6}$$  $$\\ \color{blue}\text{Rounding to 5 s.f} \color{black}\\$$ For the same reason as before, $$\\2.8400\times 10^{6}$$
